WRITING.TITLE: A cool Hobbit carving video i found on YT from a relatively small channel called Nat 1 videos
Not glass blowing per say, but very cool glass slumping interview/filming of the process, from a channel I love (a colourful, stripey plate)

WRITING.TEXT: Honestly its not mine, I thought someone would mention this at some point tho :), its a channel of a relative of mine and I just rly like it, (its my uncles if u dont believe me, and if u look at the videos u can see me commenting as 'JammyJam') Ill post a comment on his latest video saying 'I didn't make this Reddit!' just for u ;), but im sure my uncle would b happy to hear that u like it

WRITING.TITLE: Honestly, this is not my YT channel
WRITING.TEXT: I realise it looks as if im self promoting, as pointed out kindly by someone in the comments, but im honestly not, this is my uncles channel and i rly like his stuff. Ive posted a comment saying 'I didn't make this Reddit!' on his 'My first Table Top Terrain miniature house build ... go easy on me ;)' video if that helps? but i realise that there's no way for me to definitively prove it. I think it would b a lot worse if I promoted someone elses content as my own, but let me know in the comments below what I need to know about posting other peoples content and im all ears

Im very new to Reddit, so i didnt rly know the rules, and from now on ill put the link in the description just to be safe, thx for letting me know about the restrictions, im not sure if they apply to me, but like I said im going to b more careful. However, I DID NOT MAKE THIS AND THIS IS NOT MY YT CHANNEL, i rly dont like it when people think im a liar, rly rubs me the wrong way, but i completely understand how it looked, and it did look bad;), so from now on ill b a bit more careful and post in the comments instead

Just wanted to say, i have posted quite a lot of material from this channel and i realise that it looks like im a liar and im self-promoting, but im not, this is my uncles YT channel and i just rly like it and want more people to see it. Im 'jammyjam' in the comments of this video, and ill comment 'I did not make this Reddit' down below. I also dont want people giving credit where its not due, this is honestly not my work! PS: Thx for all the upvotes ;)
More details, this is my uncles YT channel, not mine, im JammyJam in the comments below the video (the name 'JammyJam' was taken on Reddit :( so i settled for subject8695 instead)
Thx, I get the picture :)
Ok, is this the same guy??
I dunno, maybe i know u in real life...

He did a drawing video of it, if u r interested [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IWDrK1N7wJ4](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IWDrK1N7wJ4)

WRITING.TITLE: My uncle carved Gandalf into a candle!

WRITING.TEXT: A video of him carving it, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hnaAsdfd6os amp;t=15s](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hnaAsdfd6os amp;t=15s)

WRITING.TITLE: I took this photo while on holiday in Wales, 'Decisions'
I did this stack in Scotland and then the tide came in around it, I think it looks pretty cool
Soho, London

WRITING.TEXT: I took this photo in Soho London because I liked the body position of the man centre frame as it seemed to me to bring a bit of a story to my photo. I also really like taking photos of alleyways and this was a particularly interesting one due to the cobbled pavement and rustic feel. I took the photo with leading lines of the buildings in mind so that there was a clear direction for the photo. Shutter Speed - gt; 1/160s F-stop - gt; 6.3 ISO - gt; 400 Any feedback would be appreciated, specifically how I could do the framing better or colour editing
Thx! The actual stack itself wasn't that difficult but I saw the low tide and thought it would look really cool when the tide came up, and it did!

WRITING.TITLE: My uncle's first stone carving, for my Nana's birthday!
A stack of four rocks I did, this one fell down pretty quickly!

WRITING.TEXT: Thanks a lot for the feedback! I'm very new to photography and I probably don't know what I'm talking about ;), I will definitely keep that in mind for next time, now that you mention it, it would look a lot better had I been in the centre!
PS, your photos are awesome

WRITING.TITLE: People at the end of an alleyway in Soho, London

WRITING.TEXT: This photo is another photo taken in Soho London, I liked the way the alleyway framed the people walking by so I waited for some people to walk by and then took this shot. I also liked the way the alleyway was really grubby and moody and then opens up onto a bright street at the end. F-stop - gt; 5.6 Shutter speed - gt; 1/60s ISO - gt; 400 PS, let me know if the motion blur/out of focus of the people adds to the photo or takes away, personally I quite like it, but I don't really trust my own opinion

Old Nikon d50 with an 18-55mm lens, it's good enough for the sort of photos I want to take, especially since I'm pretty much just doing this as a hobby (I tried putting some on a stock site, but I wasn't getting anywhere and it took the fun out of photography), but yeah, photography is very fun and a lot harder than I expected! (I mean that in the best possible way)
Thanks again for the feedback! I definitely agree that it would be a good idea to crop out the sides, will remember that for next time

WRITING.TITLE: Shark mouth and crab shell

WRITING.TEXT: I took this photo while at my grandparents house as they have lots of cool little things on their shelves. I liked the murky/moody feel that it had, especially after colour editing and increasing contrast, and I thought it quite nicely portrayed the concepts of death and the predator prey dynamic. F-stop - gt; 7.1 Shutter speed - gt; 1/160s ISO - gt; 1600 I would quite like feedback on the colour editing for this photo, what is good/what could be done better
Thx, I'm not sure what rotary tool he used, but there is a link in the description of this video to the drill bits he used, I'll ask him what rotary tool he used
Thanks, I'll definitely crop it!
The tool is called Performance 140W

WRITING.TITLE: Another rock stack and a rock bridge I did in Scotland

WRITING.TEXT: No, it was actually small enough that I could press the rocks against the surface of one of the large rocks and stack them that way before I wedged the stack into the other large rock. Towards the end both my arms were trying to hold the horizontal stack against the large rock without it all falling apart, which it did quite a few times! I also made sure I found all the right rocks before I started, flat and preferably slightly wedged shaped. Any more rocks and it would have collapsed
No problem!

WRITING.TITLE: My uncles hobbit painting tutorial, part 3, he carved it himself as well

WRITING.TEXT: Here is the full process if u r interested: Carving from block of wood Part 1 - [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hQ3wV...](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hQ3wVBa9ZkY) Detailed work Part 2 - [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s3Zov...](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s3Zov4BNyr8)

WRITING.TITLE: Wedgewood cups in my kitchen

WRITING.TEXT: I took this photo in my kitchen because I liked the leading lines of the shelves leading to the final cup at the end of the row of cups. F-stop - gt; 5.6 Shutter speed - gt; 1/10s ISO - gt; 400 I would like to know any feedback you have, but specifically what you would call the aesthetic of this photo.

WRITING.TITLE: The last rock stack I did while in Scotland
Shower, sink, stool

WRITING.TEXT: This shot was actually a bit of an accident as I placed the stool in the shower so that I could sit comfortably while taking a different photo, but then noticed that the stool in the shower fitted in a sort of weird way to tell a story which I cannot quite put my finger on... Shutter speed - gt; 1/30s F-stop - gt; 3.5 ISO - gt; 1600 I would really like any feedback, but specifically on what concepts this photo gives across, and/or a good title for this photo

WRITING.TITLE: [Question]: Can I ask for a review of my uncle's YouTube channel/video?
WRITING.TEXT: I often do filming for my uncle's YouTube channel and want to help him make his channel better, and I know that you are only allowed to post your own content on here, but I feel like this is a bit of a grey area, any thoughts?

WRITING.TITLE: My uncle painted the terrain for our DnD game with watercolours
A light and vent

WRITING.TEXT: I was going for a minimalist look for this one and I also liked the dichotomy between the light and the vent. Other than that I do not really know why I like this photo so much, I can definitely see that to some people it seems very unimpressive, let me know your thoughts on whether or not you like the aesthetic/style of this photo. Shutter speed - gt; 1/200 F-stop - gt; 3.5 ISO - gt; 400
Thx, it was a fun map to play a one shot on
Fair enough, I think i'm the only one that likes it

I said dichotomy because they are both circles and one is bright and one is dark, but I think it's one of those weird things where I'm the only one that likes it, I try to filter out those photos (there are quite a few) before posting, but it's sometimes difficult for me to figure out if other people r going to like the photo

WRITING.TITLE: Through the bath?

WRITING.TEXT: Thx! It isn't actually shot beneath the bath, I used a mirror at the bottom of the bath and then rotated the image 180 degrees. If you look closely you can see that the plug and chain are reflected. I'm pretty sure that makes it count as an illusion, because it makes you think your looking at something you're not, but I might be wrong...
Soz, got my definitions slightly confused, people on this sub obviously still like it tho, so I think it all worked out ok in the end
Thx, in future if I do anymore photos of this sort I'll be sure to post them there!

WRITING.TITLE: My uncle built and then painted a miniature house, looks rly cool and will be awesome for DnD!

WRITING.TEXT: He made a tutorial as well if u r interested: Part 1 - gt; [https://youtu.be/087dkqjFU6M](https://youtu.be/087dkqjFU6M) Part 2 - gt; [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VgGR31\_0vU0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VgGR31_0vU0)
Haha, it's more stable than it looks, if that makes you feel better
I did use a mirror though, it's not actually shot through the bath

Looks great! I would agree that the music is a bit loud at some points, but you've already acknowledged that. The only thing I would suggest that I don't think has been mentioned by anyone else is that the video might be better with the photographs shown throughout after you have taken each photo, rather than just a slideshow at the end. But other than that it's great!

I like the channel banner and the production quality of the videos is rly good, especially the drawings. The thumbnails seem good as well, nice and catchy, however sometimes it seems to me that they r slightly unrelated to the video, but that's very minor. Everything is rly good tho, the only thing other thing I would change is the frequency at which u post, cuz it seems the videos r very spaced out, but only do what u can manage
Ah i see, in that case u r releasing on a regular basis, keep it up!

Ur expression is not wildly enthusiastic, but I don't think it needs to be for the type of content u r making, and ur lines seem a good length to me. I think the main thing u can do is just power through, keep at it and improve the little things, making ur drawings even better, the jokes even funnier etc (these r already pretty good and improvement will naturally come with practice)

WRITING.TITLE: [Review Video] Stone carving video, which I did a lot of the filming for
WRITING.TEXT: [Rock carving video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MO_jnjH1b1w) This is from my uncle's arts and crafts channel, not my own, however I did a lot of the filming (almost all the outdoor shots) for this particular video, and a lot of filming on his channel in general, so I hope that qualifies this as at least partly my own work. Self review: I am happy with most of the shots I did in this video, I tried to be as creative as possible with the shots I took. I think there is definitely room for improvement with the flow between the shots, so if anyone has any ideas about shot transitions then I would really like to hear them. Feel free to give other criticisms as well, and I will feed them back to my uncle. [Review 1](https://www.reddit.com/r/youtubers/comments/j26den/review_video_hey_i_am_working_on_a_new_action/g75o6v6?utm_source=share amp;utm_medium=web2x amp;context=3) [Review 2](https://www.reddit.com/r/youtubers/comments/j2b1wt/channel_critique_i_make_storytime_animatic_videos/g76cflu?utm_source=share amp;utm_medium=web2x amp;context=3)

WRITING.TITLE: Tiny mushrooms tutorial

WRITING.TEXT: Wow! Thanks so much for taking the time to write such insightful feedback! I don't do professional camera work for a living, but I am very flattered. I would agree with your comment about the autofocus, I definitely aim to get better at using manual focus and I have already fed back to my uncle about the end card (I don't like it either), I think it was something he was just trying out and most of his other videos don't end like that. I really enjoy film work and your feedback has really encouraged me to do more. Thanks again!
Thanks for the feedback, I will try and get more involved with the footage in my uncle's future videos

Thanks for the feedback, this is my second or third time trying to shoot B-roll (my uncle is an experienced editor and he edited these shots together really well I think), so I think it will get better over time, I also need to figure out how to use manual focus and definitely try to frame better. I will feedback the editing advice about colour grading and stabilization to my uncle

WRITING.TITLE: Witch-king of Angmar, by Nat 1 videos
Goblin statue carving and painting by my uncle

WRITING.TITLE: Goblin carving by my uncle

WRITING.TEXT: Carving [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RmmLVeQ_MNI) if u like this

WRITING.TITLE: [Art] Goblin statue, by my uncle

WRITING.TEXT: My uncle initially used a carving knife to whittle out the main bits and then went in with a Dremel to smooth it out and add the finer details, such as the fingers, the toes and the face. Then he put a black wash over it and then finished with some grey paint dry brushing to add that weathered look. This Goblin Gargoyle is a piece that he is going to use in some upcoming DND games, along with all the other terrain pieces he has made. Here's the carving and painting [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RmmLVeQ_MNI) if u like this.

WRITING.TITLE: A Terrain build with a cottage, by 'Nat 1 videos'

WRITING.TEXT: The crafting [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tvyZ2X1fDOw), if u r interested

Haha, he was a bit annoying, but I still liked the cartoon LOTR. #8203; PS: this is actually a [carving](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hQ3wVBa9ZkY amp;list=PL4XGLSW2UG_iWFeZgN0Jmgl9G7V1OuKdd) from Bass wood, not a sculpture, but a sculpture from my uncle might be cool at some point tho

Thx!

Glad u like it! My uncle makes lots of different projects like this on his YT channel, and for this build he has a tutorial [series](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hQ3wVBa9ZkY amp;list=PL4XGLSW2UG_iWFeZgN0Jmgl9G7V1OuKdd). He has lots of other videos and tutorials on this sort of stuff as well, but if u want to search elsewhere for good tutorials there is a guy called 'Doug Linker' who has some good tutorials for whittling as well. The general process he went through for this build was initial sketches of the design, applying those sketches to a block of Basswood, doing some rough whittling with standard carving knives to get the body, then using a dremel to get the finer details, then painting and finally dry brushing to give it that textured look.
# THX!!
